Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Story:
My phone buzzed in my pocket as I scanned the next address on my delivery app. It was already late afternoon, and I was running behind—one package had been delayed at the warehouse, and now I was hustling to make up for lost time. As I pulled up to the next house, my phone vibrated again. This time, it was a message from Mom: “Haven’t heard from you this weekend. Everything okay?” I knew she worried if I didn’t check in, especially since I’d promised to text her every Saturday. 

But right now, I was supposed to be focused on my job—delivering this package before the customer started calling the office to complain. My supervisor had made it clear: late deliveries meant bad reviews, and too many of those could cost me my job. I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing down on me. Should I take a minute to reassure Mom, or keep moving to stay on schedule? My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between being a good child and a reliable delivery person, knowing I couldn’t be both at this moment.
